column3: Applicants must have graduated from the B.S.W. program within five years of matriculation into the MSW program with a 3.2 cumulative GPA or 3.3 Social Work major (4.0 scale). Advanced Standing Program: The M.Social Work program considers advanced standing for exceptional students with undergraduate degrees from accredited baccalaureate social work programs. This program option is offered in Durham and online.

column2: How many thesis credits do I need to complete for my program?
column3: There is no specific credit requirement for the Ph.D., though students must take required core courses and meet competency requirements. The Integrative Biology Program specifies the following requirements: ( BIOL 901 Introductory Graduate Seminar); 2 courses in experimental design/analysis; 1 course in writing/communication; and an ethics requirement (either RCR training and/or a graduate level class in ethics).

column2: What is the difference between GRAD 800 and GRAD 900?
column3: Students must be enrolled in the 800 level of the course in order to obtain graduate credit. These courses may be cross-listed with 700-level courses and taught simultaneously to both graduate and undergraduate students.

column2: What is full time status?
column3: There is no specific credit requirement for the Ph.D., though students must take required core courses and meet competency requirements. The Integrative and Organismal Biology Program specifies the following requirements: ( BIOL 901 Introductory Graduate Seminar); 2 courses in experimental design/analysis; 1 course in writing/communication; and an ethics requirement (either RCR training and/or a graduate level class in ethics).

column2: When can students in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program begin their capstone experience?
column3: Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) is offered in traditional and accelerated formats each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and an Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits) and the Capstone experience (3-9 credits). Traditional full-time enrolled students will be able to finish the degree in 18 months. UNH Bachelor's degree students entering into the Accelerated Master’s program as full time students won't have that information.

column2: Does the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program integrate academic and professional preparation?
column3: Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) is offered in traditional and accelerated formats each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and an Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits) and the Capstone experience (3-9 credits). Traditional full-time enrolled students will be able to finish the degree in 18 months. UNH Bachelor's degree students entering into the Accelerated Master’s program as full time students won't have that information.

column2: How is the scientific method applied in the biotechnology: industrial and biomedical sciences (m.s.) program?
column3: The MS Biotech:IBMS program welcomes students from varied scientific and other backgrounds who have the required basic skills to succeed in the degree program. Normally, this background includes completion of a Bachelor’s degree (GPA > 3.0) with an introductory biology two-course sequence with lab,  genetics course (lab not required), and at least one semester of organic chemistry. Students with non-biomedical Bachelor's degrees with these skills are encouraged to apply for admission as an Accelerated student if they meet the pre-requisite requirements above.

column3: Admission requirements for the Integrative Biology Graduate Program (M.S.) are: ( BIOL 901 Introductory Graduate Seminar ); 2 courses in experimental design/analysis; 1 course in writing/communication; and an ethics requirement (either RCR training and/or a graduate level class in ethics). Degree Conferral: All degree requirements and coursework must be completed prior to the degree conferral date. Graduate students must have  cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher in order to graduate.

column2: Can Information Technology (M.S.) students begin an internship early in their studies?
column3: The total credits required for Computer Science (CS) is 800 - CS 800. Students are required to enroll in at least 1 credit of Internship Experience upon successful completion of nine credits in the program. Comp 891 , COMP 892 ; or COMP 993 may be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits. Graduate credits are earned in courses numbered from 800 through 999. column2: Is there a specific credit requirement for the internship course in the Information Technology (M.S.) program?
column3: The total credits required for Computer Science (CS) is 800 - CS 800. Students are required to enroll in at least 1 credit of Internship Experience upon successful completion of nine credits in the program. Comp 891 , COMP 892 ; or COMP 993 may be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits. Graduate credits are earned in courses numbered from 800 through 999. In rare cases graduate degree students may petition to earn graduate credit for up to 12 crédits in 700-­level courses, provided the credits were taken in an program other than the one in which the student is seeking the degree and

column2: What is the total number of credits required to complete the Master’s Thesis Option at UNH Manchester?
column3: There is no specific credit requirement for the Ph.D., though students must take required core courses and meet competency requirements. The Integrative Biology Program specifies the following requirements: ( BIOL 901 Introductory Graduate Seminar); 2 courses in experimental design/analysis; 1 course in writing/communication; and an ethics requirement (either RCR training and/or a graduate level class in ethics).

column3: Graduate credit is only granted for courses completed with a grade of B-­ or higher. Many programs require substantially more than the minimum 30 credits.

column2: Can programs set stricter academic standards than the Graduate School?
column3: Academic Standards: Each individual program may set and announce standards for coursework, examinations, and/or research achievement that are more rigorous than the Graduate School standard.

column2: What is the deadline to appeal a dismissal decision?
column3: A student must submit a letter and any supporting documents to the program chairperson and the dean of the Graduate School within ten (10) business days after the dismissal notification. The appeal should provide specific evidence, context, or mitigating factors that the student believes should be considered in reviewing the decision.

column2: How many graduate credits are required for a master’s degree at UNH?
column3: A minimum of 30 graduate credits is required for all master’s degrees. Many programs require substantially more than the minimum 30 credits. Individual program requirements are outlined in the program descriptions of this catalog. Graduate credits are earned in courses numbered 800-­999. In rare cases graduate degree students may petition to earn graduate credit for up to 12 credits in 700-­level courses, provided the credits were taken in a program other than that in which the student is seeking the degree and provided such courses are approved by the Student's adviser, graduate program coordinator, and the dean of the Graduate School. column2: What are the residency requirements for the Ph.D.?
column3: A minimum of three academic years of graduate study is required for the Ph.D. degree. Resident graduate work done at other universities may be counted toward the minimum requirement upon approval of the guidance committee and the Graduate School, but one full academic year must be in residence at the University of New Hampshire.

column2: When is a Ph.D. student advanced to candidacy and what form is required?
column3: A Ph.D. student is advanced to candidacy for the degree by the dean of the Graduate School after the student has passed the qualifying examination.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Candidacy (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=student%20is%20advanced%20to%20candidacy%20for%20the%20degree%20by%20the%20dean%20of%20the%20Graduate%20School%20upon%20recommendation%20of%20the%20graduate%20program%20coordinator%20after%20the%20student)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Candidacy)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Candidacy (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=%2ANote%3A%20If%20the%20doctoral%20candidacy%20form%20is%20received%20before%20the%20final%20day%20to%20register%20for%20the%20current%20semester%2C%20then%20candidacy%20shall%20be%20effective%20immediately.)", "- Mathematics Education (Ph.D.) - Mathematics Education (Ph.D.) - Applying (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/mathematics-statistics/mathematics-education-phd/#:~:text=Students%20are%20advanced%20to%20candidacy%20after%20meeting%20the%20following%20requirements%3A)", "- Statistics (Ph.D.) - Statistics (Ph.D.) - Degree Requirements (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/mathematics-statistics/statistics-phd/#:~:text=Students%20are%20advanced%20to%20candidacy%20after%20meeting%20the%20following%20requirements%3A)", "- Mathematics Education (Ph.D.) - Mathematics Education (Ph.D.) - Applying (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/mathematics-statistics/mathematics-education-phd/)", "- Statistics (Ph.D.) - Statistics (Ph.D.) - Degree Requirements (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/mathematics-statistics/statistics-phd/)"]

column2: What are the Ph.D. time limits at UNH?
column3: The Ph.D. must be completed within eight years of matriculation (enrollment after admission) or within seven years if the student entered with a master's degree in the same field.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Doctoral%20Time%20Limits)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Doctoral Time Limits (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Years%20on%20leave%20do%20not%20count%20toward%20the%20time%20limit.)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Requirements - Doctoral Research (999) (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=students%20at%20candidacy%20must%20register%20for%20999%20each%20semester%20during%20the%20academic%20year%2C%20even%20if%20the%20minimum%20requirement%20has%20been%20met.)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Requirements - Residency (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=A%20minimum%20of%20three%20academic%20years%20of%20graduate%20study%20is%20required%20for%20the%20Ph.D%20degree.)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Ph.D.)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Requirements - Residency (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: What are the key rules for the Accelerated Master’s program?
column3: The Accelerated Master’s Program is a program designed to prepare students for graduate school.
column4: ["- Admissions - Admissions (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/admissions/#:~:text=Accelerated%20Master%27s%20Program)"]

column2: What is the minimum grade to receive graduate credit?
column3: Graduate credit is only granted for courses completed with a grade of B-­ or higher. Individual programs may have stricter requirements, and those are published with their degree program requirements.
column4: ["- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Graduate%20credit%20is%20only%20granted%20for%20courses%20completed%20with%20a%20grade%20of%20B-%C2%AD%20or%20higher.)"]

column2: Can graduate students take courses pass/fail?
column3: A graduate student may petition to take undergraduate courses on a pass/fail basis. This petition must be approved by the end of the add period for the term the course is taken. Courses at the 700-­level approved for graduate credit cannot be taken for pass and fail to make adequate progress in other aspects of their graduate program. Academic Regulations and Degree Requirements: Graduate courses Academic Standards: Each individual program may set and announce standards for coursework, examinations, and/or research achievement that are more rigorous than the Graduate School standard. Thus, students may be dismissed if they accumulate fewer than 9

column3: An AF grade is considered the same as an F grade.

column2: What happens when a graduate course is repeated?
column3: Graduate students must obtain written permission of their adviser, graduate program coordinator, and the endorsement of the Graduate School dean before the adjustment will be made. Only repeated courses taken at UNH will alter the cumulative grade-­point average. Failing a required course is grounds for dismissal.

column2: How many times per year are graduate degrees conferred at UNH?

column2: Do I have to file an intent to graduate?
column3: Students who do not file an intent-to-graduate will not have their degree awarded. More information on this process is available on the Graduate School’s website. Degree Conferral: All degree requirements and coursework must be completed prior to the degree conferral date. Graduate students must have a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher in order to graduate.

column2: Who can participate in the May commencement ceremony?
column3: Doctoral, Master's, Ed.S., and certificate students who earn their degrees in the preceding September and December are invited to participate in commencement ceremonies.
column4: ["- Graduation - Graduation - Commencement (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/graduation/#:~:text=The%20annual%20commencement%20ceremony%20is%20held%20in%20May.)", "- Graduation - Graduation - Commencement (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/graduation/#:~:text=Master%27s%2C%20Ed.S.%2C%20and%20certificate%20students%20who%20expect%20to%20complete%20their%20degree%20program%20in%20May%2C%20as%20well%20as%20those%20who%20expect%20to%20complete%20their%20programs%20at%20the%20end)", "- Graduation - Graduation - Commencement (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/graduation/#:~:text=All%20graduate%20students%20who%20intend%20to%20participate%20in%20the%20May%20ceremony%20must%20register%20to%20attend%20through%20the%20Commencement%20Office.)", "- Graduation - Graduation - Commencement (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/graduation/#:~:text=For%20more%20information%20on%20how%20to%20register%20for%20commencement%20please%20visit%20the%20UNH%20Commencement%20Website%20.)", "- Graduation - Graduation - Commencement (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/graduation/#:~:text=Doctoral%20students%20must%20have%20completed%20all%20requirements%20for%20the%20degree%20by%20the%20published%20deadlines%20for%20May%20in%20order%20to%20participate%20in%20the%20May%20ceremony.)", "- Graduation - Graduation - Commencement (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/graduation/)"]

column2: Where can I find the intent-to-graduate deadlines?
column3: Students who do not file an intent-to-graduate will not have their degree awarded. More information on this process is available on the Graduate School’s website: http://www.gradschool.unh.edu. Application Deadlines: Graduate degrees are conferred three times per year (September 1, December 31, and May (date varies) ). All students MUST file An intent­to­graduate through Webcat by the appropriate deadline specified on The UNH Academic Calendar. These are updated on an annual basis and may be found on each of the program pages. Applications deadlines may vary by student populations, including current UN

column2: Who issues official transcripts and what is required before receiving a diploma?
column3: A student is required to satisfy University accounts before the Registrar will issue a diploma as evidence of work done at the University.

column2: What is the minimum passing grade for graduate students?
column3: A graduate student may petition to take undergraduate courses on a pass/fail basis. This petition must be approved by the end of the add period for the term the course is taken.

column2: What is an IA grade?
column3: The grade earned will replace the "IA" if the work has been completed. In the case of doctoral research, once the dissertation is deemed complete, only the final term of enrollment will be assigned a "CR". Prior semester IA grades will remain on the official transcript.

column2: Can I take a course pass/fail?
column3: A graduate student may petition to take undergraduate courses on a pass/fail basis. This petition must be approved by the end of the add period for the term the course is taken. Courses at the 700-­level approved for graduate credit cannot be taken for pass or fail.

column2: Can I transfer credits into my program?
column3: Credit Transfer: A maximum of 12 credits taken by a student prior to matriculation (internal and external combined) can be applied to an degree program. Transfer credits must be formally approved and appear on the UNH transcript in order for them to count towards the degree requirements.

column2: Can I do a dual degree?
column3: The Graduate School allows UNH students to pursue two degrees and count credits toward both degrees under the circumstances detailed below. Dual degrees should be interpreted to include separate majors within the same degree, or a combination of two different degrees. Students will receive separate diplomas for each degree program.

column2: Can I appeal a dismissal?
column3: Generally, dismissed students will not be able to continue in classes pending the outcome of the appeal, but the program chairperson may make a final decision regarding if the student can continue with conditions.

column2: How do I reach degree candidacy?
column3: The degree must meet admission requirements, develop and complete an approved program of study in consultation with their guidance committee, complete required coursework, undergo an annual assessment review by the Doctoral Advisory Committee, draft a dissertation proposal to advance to candidacy, write and present the dissertation, and pass the final oral examination.

column2: How long do I have to complete my master’s degree?
column3: All graduate work for any master’s degree must normally be completed within four years from the date of matriculation (enrollment following admission) in the program.

column2: Do I need RCR training?
column3: The Graduate Council has mandated that all incoming Ph.D. students complete RCR training by the end of their first semester. To fulfill its obligations, UNH has embarked on a program on the responsible conduct of research and scholarly activity (RCR) to:
column4: ["- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Requirements - RESPONSIBLE CONDUCT OF RESEARCH (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=students%20complete%20RCR%20training%20approved%20by%20the%20Graduate%20School%20by%20the%20end%20of%20their%20first%20semester.)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Requirements - RESPONSIBLE CONDUCT OF RESEARCH (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=To%20fulfill%20its%20obligations%2C%20UNH%20has%20embarked%20on%20a%20program%20on%20the%20responsible%20conduct%20of%20research%20and%20scholarly%20activity%20%28RCR%29%20to%3A)"]

column2: What is a guidance committee?
column3: A guidance committee should be appointed by the program faculty as soon as possible after a student has begun study for the Ph.D. degree.

column2: What is a non-terminal degree?

Students must complete the master’s degree requirements for their particular program as noted in the Graduate Catalog. Degree Requirements: Department of Education

column2: How many thesis credits do I need to complete for my program?
column3: Students must complete at least 6 but no more than 10 thesis credits. Students are advised to review their program's degree requirements as the exact number of thesis credit that are required for each degree will be determined by the faculty of the individual programs.

column2: Where do I file an intent to graduate?
column3: Students must file an intent-­to-graduate through Webcat by the appropriate deadline specified on the UNH Academic Calendar . Students who do not file An intent to graduate will not have their degree awarded. More information on this process is available at the Graduate School website: http://www.gradschool.unh.edu.

column2: What is the deadline to file an intent to graduate?
column3: Students must file an intent-to-graduate through Webcat by the appropriate deadline specified on the UNH Academic Calendar. Students who fail to complete all requirements for the degree must be completed within four years from the date of matriculation (enrollment following admission). Students failing to make adequate advancement toward completion of the program are subject to dismissal in advance. Extensions to the four-year time limit will be considered on a case-by-case basis.

column2: Can I take courses without applying?
column3: Non-Degree Students: Individuals holding a bachelor's degree from an accredited college or university may register for graduate courses through The Office of Continuing Education. These individuals are designated as "non-degree students" and non-course students are not required to file an application for admission to the Graduate School. Registering for 9 or more credits requires special permission.

column2: Does UNH offer student health insurance?
column3: University policy requires full-time degree students that are enrolled in at least one in-person course to have health insurance as a condition of enrollment. Some students have the option of waiving this requirement if they present proof of adequate coverage; alternatively, students can acquire an affordable health benefits plan sponsored by the University: the UNH Student Health Benefits Plan (SHBP).

column2: Can I take a leave of absence?
column3: Students who, because of extenuating circumstances, are unable to pursue their graduate program may request a leave of absence. Such circumstances may include medical reasons, military obligation, family emergencies, or hardship.

column2: How do I withdraw from the program?
column3: A student may request to fully withdraw from their graduate degree program during any semester by obtaining a withdrawal form from the Graduate School website. Students who formally withdraw are required to apply for readmission if they subsequently desire to resume their academic program.

column2: How long does it typically take to complete the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The M.S. in Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (MS) program is offered in traditional and accelerated formats each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and an Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits); and the Capstone experience (3-9 credits). Traditional full-time enrolled students will be able complete the degree in 18 months. UNH Bachelor's degree students entering into the Accelerated Master’s program as part of their degree program. column2: What is the purpose of the Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Students are required to complete the core curriculum courses (chosen based on market analysis and additional industry input) to establish graduate-level skill competencies in the areas of protein biochemistry, molecular biology, and cell biology. Core requirements may be waived in those instances where the Admissions Committee ascertains that the student already possesses the knowledge and skills provided through these Core Curriculum courses.

column2: Who helps Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) students develop a curriculum plan?
column3: Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.): focuses on the application of the biological and biochemical sciences, and particularly genetics, to the preparation of new and enhanced biomematic, industrial, agricultural, or environmental products. Graduate instruction in this area would include molecular biology, cell and tissue culturing, protein biochemistry, genetic engineering, cells imaging and phenotyping. These courses offered by other academic programs include: bioengineering, biomanufacturing; entrepreneurship and business management; bioregulatory science (including administrative law, intellectual property,

column2: What is the main goal of the Capstone Experience in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The Capstone Experience in Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program at the University of New Hampshire offers its students innovative experiential learning opportunities and delivers a content-rich, skills-based, and highly versatile curriculum for individuals seeking to advance their careers in the biotechnology, pharmaceutical, or biomanufacturing sectors.

column2: What is the main academic focus of the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Biotechnology focuses on the application of the biological and biochemical sciences, and particularly genetics, to the preparation of new and enhanced biomedical, industrial, agricultural and environmental products.

column2: What is the relationship between core courses and elective courses in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The MS Biotech:IBMS core curriculum is centered around research project team-based lab courses. This provides you with important industry-relevant transferrable job skills, such as clear communication, cooperation and relationship building, teamwork and conflict resolution, and creative problem-solving and strategic thinking. These transfererable skills are developed hand-in-hand with the wet-lab skills.

column2: What is the minimum total credit requirement for graduation from the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) is offered in traditional and accelerated formats, each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and an Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits) and the Capstone experience (3-9 credits). Traditional full-time enrolled students will be able complete the degree in as little as 12 months.

column3: Admission to the accelerated master's is highly competitive. Students wishing to pursue this option must have a grade point average greater than 3.2 at the time of application.

column2: When can eligible students in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) Accelerated Option begin taking graduate courses for dual credit?
column3: Students who have been admitted to the program may register for a maximum of 12 credits of 800-level courses prior to completing their bachelor's degree. Such courses may, upon recommendation of the department and approval by the Graduate School, count toward both the bachelors and masters degrees. A 3.20 cumulative grade­-point average is normally required to be considered for admission into the Accelerated Master’s program, though some departments may have higher GPA requirements. The M.S. in Biotech:IBMS is offered in traditional and accelerated formats each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4

column2: What is the overall purpose of the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) Accelerated Master’s Option?
column3: The M.S. in Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (MS Biotech:IBMS) program at the University of New Hampshire is a STEM-designated graduate degree program that offers its students innovative experiential learning opportunities and delivers an content-rich, skills-based, and highly versatile curriculum for individuals seeking to advance their careers in the biotechnology, pharmaceutical, or biomanufacturing sectors. Graduate instruction in this area would include molecular biology, cell and tissue culturing, protein biological development, bioinformatics, functional and comparative genomics; applied immunology, DNA

column2: What core knowledge areas will students master in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.): The MS Biotech:IBMS program has a core foundation in the theory and wet-laboratory skills of cell and tissue biology and culturing; protein and immunologic methods and therapeutics; and the molecular biotechnology of nucleic acids.

column2: What laboratory skills will students develop in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.): Core Curriculum The MS Biotech:IBMS core curriculum is centered around research project team-based lab courses. This provides you with important industry-relevant transferrable job skills, such as clear communication, cooperation and relationship building, teamwork and conflict resolution, and creative problem-solving and strategic thinking. These transfererable skills are developed hand-in-hand with the wet-lab skills. column2: In the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program, how many hours of academic work does each credit typically represent?
column3: In the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program, students must complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), e-learning, recitation, laboratory work, fieldwork, performance, internships, and practica.

column2: According to the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) description, what learning modes are combined?
column3: Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.): Designed for working professionals and those with a strong interest in cybersecurity, the program combines in-class and online learning on how to develop, engineer and operate secure information systems. You will learn the theoretical underpinnings of information security and have opportunities to apply your knowledge and skills to real-world scenarios and authentic project experiences.

column2: How does the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) program provide applied experience?
column3: Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.): Designed for working professionals and those with a strong interest in cybersecurity, the program combines in-class and online learning on how to develop, engineer and operate secure information systems. You will learn the theoretical underpinnings of information security and have opportunities to apply your knowledge and skills to real-world scenarios and authentic project experiences.

column2: What key outcome does the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) program prepare graduates for?
column3: Career Opportunities: The Cybersecurity Engineering program cultivates strategic thinking, policy development, and risk-management skills for students interested in careers in business or government. The program features full-time faculty and industry experts who help blend cybersecurity strategy and policy with preparedness, incident response, recovery and resilience – the heart of our security studies discipline.

column2: How does the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) position graduates for organizational impact?
column3: Career Opportunities: Graduates of the Cybersecurity Engineering program are able to identify, analyze and respond to the complex information security threats that are increasingly common in today's digital landscape. You'll learn skills in core and advanced info security, preparing you to develop, integrate and evaluate secure IT systems and services for any organization.

column3: Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.): Designed for working professionals and those with a strong interest in cybersecurity, the program combines in-class and online learning on how to develop, engineer and operate secure information systems. You will learn the theoretical underpinnings of information security and have opportunities to apply your knowledge and skills to real-world scenarios and authentic project experiences.

column2: According to the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) requirements page, how many total graduate credits are required for the degree?
column3: A minimum of 30 graduate credits is required for all master's degrees. Many programs require substantially more than the minimum 30 credits. Individual program requirements are outlined in the program descriptions of this catalog. Graduate credits are earned in courses numbered 800-­999. In rare cases graduate degree students may petition to earn graduate credit for up to 12 credits in 700-­level courses, provided the credits have been taken in a program other than that in which the student is seeking the degree and provided such courses are approved by the Student’s adviser, graduate program coordinator, and the dean of the Graduate School. Such courses must be taken

column2: Where is the Information Technology (M.S.) program offered and what schedule flexibility is there?
column3: The M.S. in Information Technology program is offered at the University's urban campus in Manchester, a city that embraces cultural diversity, the program welcomes students from all over the word. With classes scheduled during the day and in the evening in fall, spring, and summer terms, it gives students the flexibility to enroll full- or part-time.

column2: How does the Information Technology (M.S.) support students’ schedules?
column3: Information Technology (M.S.) is a professional graduate program in the applied and fast-changing field of Information technology. The program prepares students for an advanced IT or computing-related career and for advanced studies in an computing discipline. Offered at the University's urban campus in Manchester, the program welcomes student from all over the word. With classes scheduled during the day and on the evening in fall, spring, and summer terms, it gives students the flexibility to enroll full- or part-time.

column2: How many core credits are required in the Information Technology (M.S.) program?
column3: A minimum of 30 graduate credits is required for all master’s degrees. Many programs require substantially more than the minimum 30 credits. Individual program requirements are outlined in the program descriptions of this catalog. Graduate credits are earned in courses numbered 800-­999. In rare cases graduate degree students may petition to earn graduate credit for up to 12 credits in 700-­level courses, provided the credits were taken in a program other than that in which the student is seeking the degree and provided such courses are approved by the Student's adviser, graduate program coordinator, and the dean of the Graduate School. column2: When must students enroll in the internship for the Information Technology (M.S.) program?
column3: Students must enroll in the Information Technology (M.S.) program at the end of each semester. The student must apply knowledge and skills acquired through other coursework to address a research question in information technology related fields.

column3: The Master’s Project in the Information Technology (M.S.) program includes 30 credits course work and 3 credits of Master's Thesis. Students typically complete 6 credits, however, it can be taken up to 10 credits when permitted by the department by petition.

column2: How many thesis credits are required in the Information Technology (M.S.) Thesis Option?
column3: Students in the thesis option must satisfactorily complete at least 30 graduate credits, which include the credits accumulated in both the core curriculum and the university's undergraduate program. Thesis Option: During their degree program, students completing a thesis must enroll in At least 6 but no more than 10 thesis credits. Students are advised to review their program' s degree requirements as the exact number of thesis credit that are required for each degree will be determined by the faculty of the individual programs.

column2: What is the goal of the internship experience in the Information Technology (M.S.) program?
column3: The internship course provides experiential learning experience through placement in team projects. This hands-on experience allows students to gain practical skills and insights into the field of computing. By working on a collaborative project with external stakeholders, they will contribute to the development of real-world information technology products, processes, or services.

column2: Can Information Technology (M.S.) students begin an internship early in their studies?
column3: The internship provides an opportunity for MBA students to gain business experience in a professional setting, applying their course-based learning to challenges in business or non-profit enterprises. Students explore the relationship between theory and practice while completing at least 250 hours of time on site.

column2: What is the total number of graduate credits needed to complete any option in the Information Technology (M.S.) program?
column3: A minimum of 30 graduate credits is required for all master's degrees. Many programs require substantially more than the minimum 30 credits. Individual program requirements are outlined in the program descriptions of this catalog. Graduate credits are earned in courses numbered 800-­999. In rare cases graduate degree students may petition to earn graduate credit for up to 12 credits in 700-­level courses, provided the credits were taken in a program other than that in which the student is seeking the degree and provided such courses are approved by their adviser, graduate program coordinator, and the dean of the Graduate School. Petitions must include what additional requirements or expectations
